page.title: 04CANALS PAST AND PRESENT
page.content: Sometimes canals had to negotiate hills and so tunnels had to be constructed.A few of these were wide enough to allow a tow path at the side of the tunnel,some had no path at all.The longest tunnel in use today is at Dudley near Birmingham 3172 yards long.Other tunnels in use : BLISWORTH=3056 YARDS PRESTON BROOK=1239 YARDS KING'S NORTON=2726 YARDS SHORTWOOD=613 YARDS TARDEBRIGGE=580 YARDS CHIRK=459 YARDS If a tunnel did not have a towpath then the men would have to 'shaft' or 'leg' the boat through the tunnel.This involved lying on your back with your feet on the walls or roof and pushing the boat through with your legs.
